title: RL32930
content: The NLRA, as amended, establishes the framework for labor-management relations in the private sector. It aims to improve workers' bargaining power and eliminate obstacles to commerce by encouraging collective bargaining. Workers have the right to join unions and negotiate wages, hours, and working conditions. The NLRA allows workers to join unions, bargain collectively, and protects their rights. It requires employers to negotiate in good faith with chosen unions and defines unfair labor practices. The act does not apply to certain industries or exclude unauthorized workers from engaging in union activities. The NLRB enforces the NLRA independently. The NLRA allows various types of workers to engage in union activities, including unauthorized workers. The NLRB, an independent federal agency, administers and enforces the NLRA through a five-member board and General Counsel. The board resolves election disputes, determines bargaining unit composition, and handles unfair labor practice appeals. Bargaining units are groups of employees represented by a union based on shared interests. A bargaining unit is a group of employees represented by a union based on shared interests in wages, hours, and working conditions. The composition of a bargaining unit can include employees of one employer, establishment, or occupation. Guards cannot be included in the same bargaining unit as other employees, and the appropriate unit is determined by agreement between the union and employer or by the NLRB. In August 2011, the NLRB reviewed a case where CNAs at a healthcare center in Mobile, AL, petitioned to be represented by the USW. The employer argued that the bargaining unit should include all nonprofessional service and maintenance employees, not just CNAs. The CNAs assist residents with daily tasks and help move them within the facility. The CNAs at the healthcare center in Mobile, AL assist residents with daily tasks, move them within the facility, and wear nursing uniforms. They work one of three eight-hour shifts and must maintain certification from the state of Alabama. The employer argued that other employees like resident activity assistants, a staffing coordinator, and a maintenance assistant should be included in the bargaining unit. The board voted in favor (3-1) of including CNAs in the bargaining unit, along with other employees like resident activity assistants, a staffing coordinator, a maintenance assistant, a medical records clerk, and cooks. These employees have similar educational requirements as CNAs and receive similar benefits. Unlike CNAs, they are not part of the nursing department and do not work one of three eight-hour shifts. The board voted (3-1) in favor of including CNAs in the bargaining unit, agreeing that they shared a community of interest due to distinct training, certification, supervision, uniforms, pay rates, work assignments, shifts, and work areas.
